projects.title: Museum & Library staff training programme, Zanzibar, Tanzania
projects.description:
Objectives
The aim is to train staff of the House of Wonders Museum and related institutions in the field of museum object registration (Object ID), reorganization and computerization of the library and exhibition development, with topics ranging from conception, planning and budgeting to maintenance, marketing and publicity. 

Background
The National Museum of Zanzibar covers three institutes: The House of Wonders Museum, The Peace Memorial Museum and The National History Museum. The staff training programme for the National Museums of Zanzibar is conceived as on-the-job training. The project is funded by the National Museum Tanzania and the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs

Activities
KIT’s role, next to the Object ID programme is that of initiator, broker and advisor.
The programme is divided into five phases: three training sessions and two monitoring and advice missions. An individual training programme for a selected number of staff is also provided, consisting partly of internships and partly of museum courses. The whole programme is developed and is executed with regional partners, notably the Programme for Museum Development in Africa (PMDA) based in Mombassa, Kenya. The individual programmes will be executed by regional partners (probably in Kenya and South Africa). 

KIT Information & Library Services supported the National Museum of Zanzibar in the reorganization of the libraries concerned. This involved the reorganization of the library; layout and design of the store and reading room, computerization, update of library system, restoration of antiquities, and development of services to the public.

projects.title: Development and implementation Object Identification Software
projects.description:
Objectives
Realizing an internationally accessible and efficient information system in museums in 14 developing countries which offers customs agencies, law enforcers and the art trade a means to establish whether an object is stolen or not. 

Countries
Benin, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Burkina Faso, Egypt, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Mozambique, Sri Lanka, Tanzania, Vietnam, Zambia, India 

Background
Throughout the world museums and sites suffer from looting, art theft and illicit trade. Object registration is a means to help curb the illicit trade. Starting from Object ID-registration principles as formulated by the Getty Information Institute, and supported and encouraged by Unesco and ICOM, KIT has assisted museums in 14 countries to implement an improved computerized version of Object ID. Using a digital camera, photographs are taken of museum objects, which are then saved in a database with a description according to the Object ID standard. If an object is missing, the museum can send a standardized  file to custom authorities, Interpol or any other organization around the world. Introducing Object ID in the museums concerned also implied training in registration, documentation and storage- principles. 

Activities
- Installation of computers and peripherals, Internet and E-mail and Object ID software. 
- Extensive training in registration of objects and in the use of the Object ID software.
- Helpdesk and update service during several years.
- Follow-up visits to help solve problems on the spot.
